bibl.title: Ichitaro Matsutsuyu v. Henry M. White. Answer and Return.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: In the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington.
In the Matter of the Application of Ichitara Matsutsuyu to be Released on Habeas Corpus
Filed in the United States District Court
In the Matter of theApplication of Ichitara Matsutsuyu to be Released on Habeas Corpus.

Comes now John H. Sargent, Acting United States Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, Washington, and for answer to the petition and supplemental petition of the above named applicant, ICHITARA MATSUTSUYU, and for return to the Show Cause Order heretofore issued herein directed to Henry M. White, United States Commissioner of Immigration, and respectfully shows the court as follows:

That on to-wit, June 13, 1917, a warrant was duly and regularly issued by the Secretary of Labor of the United States for the arrest of the above named ICHITARA MATSUTSUYU on the ground that he was an alien found in the United States in violation of the immigration laws of United States for the reason that he was a person likely to become a public charge, at the time of his entry into the United States, and which said warrant further directed that a hearing be granted to said alien to enable him to show cause why he should not be deported in conformity of thelaw.

That thereafter pursuant to said warrant of arrest a hearing thereon was accorded to the said alien on the 27th day of August, 1919, at which said hearing said alien was present in person and by his counsel.

That at said hearing the said alien and his said counsel were then and there given notice by the United States Inspector of Immigration conducting said hearing that there was then placed against the said alien the additional charge that within five years after his entry into the UnitedStates he had been sentenced to imprisonment because of conviction in this country of a crime involving moral turpitude.
That notice was further given to the said alien and his attorney that they show cause, if any there be, why said alien should not be deported on such additional ground.
That full and fair opportunity was given to the said alien and his counsel to be held with relation to said additional charge as well as with relation to the original charge.

That thereafter upon a report of said hearing and the evidence relating to the said alien being found unlawfully in this country a warrant was duly and regularly issued by the Secretary of Labor for the deportation of the said alien.

That the said alien had a full, fair, impartial and legal hearing and is now held in custody by the United States Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle,under and pursuant to the said warrants and said proceeedings for deportation; that a copy of said warrants together with the transcript of the testimony at said hearing and of the proceedings in the matter of deportation of said alien are hereto attached, marked "Exhibit A"
WHEREFORE respondent prays that petitioner's application herein be denied.
John H. Sargent being first duly sworn on his oath, deposes and says:
That he is Acting Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, Washington; that he has read the foregoing answer and return, knows the contents thereof and that the allegations thereof are true.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 15th day of December, A.D., 1919.
Deputy Clerk, U.S. District Court, Western District of Washington
